                                    5         SEC. 2. PURPOSE; CONFORMITY WITH ORIGINAL INTENT.
                                    6            (a) PURPOSE.—The purpose of this Act is to codify certain existing laws
                                    7         relating to the National Park System as title 54, United States Code, ‘‘Na-
                                    8         tional Park Service and Related Programs’’.
                                    9            (b) CONFORMITY WITH ORIGINAL INTENT.—In the codification of laws




                                  10          by this Act, the intent is to conform to the understood policy, intent, and
                                  11          purpose of Congress in the original enactments, with such amendments and
                                  12          corrections as will remove ambiguities, contradictions, and other imperfec-



                                                                                                              2
                                    1         tions, in accordance with section 205(c)(1) of House Resolution No. 988,
                                    2         93d Congress, as enacted into law by Public Law 93–554 (2 U.S.C.
                                    3         285b(1)).

                                    1                Subtitle I—National Park System

                                    4     Sec.      Chapter 1001—General Provisions
                                          100101.       Promotion and regulation.
                                          100102.       Definitions.

                                    5         § 100101. Promotion and regulation
                                    6           (a) IN GENERAL.—The Secretary, acting through the Director of the Na-
                                    7         tional Park Service, shall promote and regulate the use of the National
                                    8         Park System by means and measures that conform to the fundamental pur-
                                    9         pose of the System units, which purpose is to conserve the scenery, natural
                                  10          and historic objects, and wild life in the System units and to provide for
                                  11          the enjoyment of the scenery, natural and historic objects, and wild life in
                                  12          such manner and by such means as will leave them unimpaired for the en-
                                  13          joyment of future generations.
                                  14            (b) DECLARATIONS.—
                                  15                   (1) 1970          DECLARATIONS.—Congress                             declares that—
                                  16                            (A) the National Park System, which began with establishment
                                  17                        of Yellowstone National Park in 1872, has since grown to include
                                  18                        superlative natural, historic, and recreation areas in every major
                                  19                        region of the United States and its territories and possessions;





                                  20                            (B) these areas, though distinct in character, are united
                                  21                        through their interrelated purposes and resources into one Na-



                                               HR 1068 IH

                                                                                                4
                                    1                       tional Park System as cumulative expressions of a single national
                                    2                       heritage;
                                    3                         (C) individually and collectively, these areas derive increased na-
                                    4                       tional dignity and recognition of their superb environmental qual-
                                    5                       ity through their inclusion jointly with each other in one System
                                    6                       preserved and managed for the benefit and inspiration of all the
                                    7                       people of the United States; and
                                    8                         (D) it is the purpose of this division to include all these areas
                                    9                       in the System and to clarify the authorities applicable to the Sys-
                                  10                        tem.
                                  11                  (2) 1978          REAFFIRMATION.—Congress               reaffirms, declares, and di-
                                  12               rects that the promotion and regulation of the various System units
                                  13               shall be consistent with and founded in the purpose established by sub-
                                  14               section (a), to the common benefit of all the people of the United
                                  15               States. The authorization of activities shall be construed and the pro-
                                  16               tection, management, and administration of the System units shall be
                                  17               conducted in light of the high public value and integrity of the System
                                  18               and shall not be exercised in derogation of the values and purposes for
                                  19               which the System units have been established, except as directly and
                                  20               specifically provided by Congress.
                                  21          § 100102. Definitions
                                  22            In this title:
                                  23                  (1) DIRECTOR.—The term ‘‘Director’’ means the Director of the Na-
                                  24               tional Park Service.
                                  25                  (2) NATIONAL           PARK SYSTEM.—The               term ‘‘National Park System’’
                                  26               means the areas of land and water described in section 100501 of this
                                  27               title.
                                  28                  (3) SECRETARY.—The term ‘‘Secretary’’ means the Secretary of the
                                  29               Interior.
                                  30                  (4) SERVICE.—The term ‘‘Service’’ means the National Park Serv-
                                  31               ice.
                                  32                  (5) SYSTEM.—The term ‘‘System’’ means the National Park System.
                                  33                  (6) SYSTEM         UNIT.—The       term ‘‘System unit’’ means one of the areas
                                  34               described in section 100501 of this title.

                                          100301.      Establishment.
                                          100302.      Directors and other employees.
                                          100303.      Effect on other laws.

                                                                                              5
                                    1         § 100301. Establishment
                                    2           There is in the Department of the Interior a service called the National
                                    3         Park Service.
                                    4         § 100302. Directors and other employees
                                    5           (a) DIRECTOR.—
                                    6                 (1) APPOINTMENT.—The Service shall be under the charge of a di-
                                    7              rector who shall be appointed by the President, by and with the advice
                                    8              and consent of the Senate.
                                    9                 (2) QUALIFICATIONS.—The Director shall have substantial experi-
                                  10               ence and demonstrated competence in land management and natural or
                                  11               cultural resource conservation.
                                  12                  (3) AUTHORITY.—Under the direction of the Secretary, the Director
                                  13               shall have the supervision, management, and control of System units.
                                  14               In the supervision, management, and control of System units contig-
                                  15               uous to national forests the Secretary of Agriculture may cooperate
                                  16               with the Service to such extent as may be requested by the Secretary.
                                  17            (b) DEPUTY DIRECTORS.—The Director shall select 2 Deputy Directors.
                                  18          One Deputy Director shall have responsibility for Service operations, and
                                  19          the other Deputy Director shall have responsibility for other programs as-
                                  20          signed to the Service.
                                  21            (c) OTHER EMPLOYEES.—The Service shall have such subordinate offi-
                                  22          cers and employees as may be appropriated for by Congress.
                                  23          § 100303. Effect on other laws
                                  24            This chapter and sections 100101(a), 100751(a), 100752, 100753, and
                                  25          102101 of this title do not affect or modify section 100902(a) of this title.

                                          100501.      Areas included in System.

                                  28          § 100501. Areas included in System
                                  29            The System shall include any area of land and water administered by the
                                  30          Secretary, acting through the Director, for park, monument, historic, park-
                                  31          way, recreational, or other purposes.
                                  32          § 100502. General management plans
                                  33            General management plans for the preservation and use of each System




                                  34          unit, including areas within the national capital area, shall be prepared and
                                  35          revised in a timely manner by the Director. On January 1 of each year,
                                  36          the Secretary shall submit to Congress a list indicating the current status

                                               HR 1068 IH

                                                                                               6
                                    1         of completion or revision of general management plans for each System
                                    2         unit. General management plans for each System unit shall include—
                                    3                 (1) measures for the preservation of the area’s resources;
                                    4                 (2) indications of types and general intensities of development (in-
                                    5              cluding visitor circulation and transportation patterns, systems, and
                                    6              modes) associated with public enjoyment and use of the area, including
                                    7              general locations, timing of implementation, and anticipated costs;
                                    8                 (3) identification of and implementation commitments for visitor car-
                                    9              rying capacities for all areas of the System unit; and
                                  10                  (4) indications of potential modifications to the external boundaries
                                  11               of the System unit, and the reasons for the modifications.
                                  12          § 100503. Five-year strategic plans
                                  13            (a) STRATEGIC           AND   PERFORMANCE PLANS.—Each System unit shall pre-
                                  14          pare and make available to the public a 5-year strategic plan and an annual
                                  15          performance plan. The plans shall reflect the Service policies, goals, and
                                  16          outcomes represented in the Service-wide strategic plan prepared pursuant
                                  17          to section 306 of title 5.
                                  18            (b) ANNUAL BUDGET.—
                                  19                  (1) IN     GENERAL.—As          a part of the annual performance plan for a
                                  20               System unit prepared pursuant to subsection (a), following receipt of
                                  21               the appropriation for the unit from the Operations of the National
                                  22               Park System account (but not later than January 1 of each year), the
                                  23               superintendent of the System unit shall develop and make available to
                                  24               the public the budget for the current fiscal year for that System unit.
                                  25                  (2) CONTENTS.—The budget shall include—
                                  26                          (A) funding allocations for resource preservation (including re-
                                  27                        source management), visitor services (including maintenance, in-
                                  28                        terpretation, law enforcement, and search and rescue), and admin-
                                  29                        istration; and
                                  30                          (B) allocations into each of the categories in subparagraph (A)
                                  31                        of all funds retained from fees collected for that year, including
                                  32                        special use permits, concession franchise fees, and recreation use
                                  33                        and entrance fees.
                                  34          § 100504. Study and planning of park, parkway, and rec-
                                  35                          reational-area facilities
                                  36            (a) IN GENERAL.—
                                  37                  (1) DEFINITION.—In this subsection, the term ‘‘State’’ means a
                                  38               State, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, and the Virgin Is-
                                  39               lands.





                                  40                  (2) STUDY.—The Secretary shall cause the Service to make a com-
                                  41               prehensive study, other than on land under the jurisdiction of the Sec-


                                                HR 1068 IH

                                                                                               7
                                    1              retary of Agriculture, of the public park, parkway, and recreational
                                    2              area programs of the United States, States, and political subdivisions
                                    3              of States and of areas of land throughout the United States that are
                                    4              or may be chiefly valuable as public park, parkway, or recreational
                                    5              areas. A study shall not be made in any State without the consent and
                                    6              approval of the State officials, boards, or departments having jurisdic-
                                    7              tion over the land. The study shall be such as, in the judgment of the
                                    8              Secretary, will provide data helpful in developing a plan for coordinated
                                    9              and adequate public park, parkway, and recreational-area facilities for
                                  10               the people of the United States.
                                  11                  (3) COOPERATION              AND AGREEMENTS WITH OTHER ENTITIES.—In
                                  12               making the study and to accomplish the purposes of this section, the
                                  13               Secretary, acting through the Director—
                                  14                          (A) shall seek and accept the cooperation and assistance of Fed-
                                  15                        eral departments or agencies having jurisdiction of land belonging
                                  16                        to the United States; and
                                  17                          (B) may cooperate and make agreements with and seek and ac-
                                  18                        cept the assistance of—
                                  19                               (i) other Federal agencies and instrumentalities; and
                                  20                               (ii) States, political subdivisions of States, and agencies
                                  21                            and instrumentalities of either of them.
                                  22                  (4) STATE        PLANNING.—For           the purpose of developing coordinated
                                  23               and adequate public park, parkway, and recreational-area facilities for
                                  24               the people of the United States, the Secretary may aid States and po-
                                  25               litical subdivisions of States in planning public park, parkway, and rec-
                                  26               reational areas and in cooperating with one another to accomplish these
                                  27               ends. Aid shall be made available through the Service acting in co-
                                  28               operation with such State agencies or agencies of political subdivisions
                                  29               of States as the Secretary considers best.
                                  30            (b) CONSENT        OF   CONGRESS        TO     AGREEMENTS BETWEEN STATES.—The
                                  31          consent of Congress is given to any 2 or more States to negotiate and enter
                                  32          into compacts or agreements with one another with reference to planning,
                                  33          establishing, developing, improving, and maintaining any park, parkway, or
                                  34          recreational area. No compact or agreement shall be effective until approved
                                  35          by the legislatures of the States that are parties to the compact or agree-
                                  36          ment and by Congress.
                                  37          § 100505. Periodic review of System
                                  38            (a) AUTHORITY          OF   SECRETARY TO CONDUCT REVIEW.—The Secretary
                                  39          shall conduct a systematic and comprehensive review of certain aspects of




                                  40          the System and on a periodic basis (but not less often than every 3 years)
                                  41          submit to the Committee on Natural Resources and the Committee on Ap-


                                               HR 1068 IH

                                                                                              8
                                    1         propriations of the House of Representatives and the Committee on Energy
                                    2         and Natural Resources and the Committee on Appropriations of the Senate
                                    3         a report on the findings of the review, together with recommendations as
                                    4         the Secretary determines to be necessary.
                                    5           (b) CONSULTATION.—In conducting and preparing the report, the Sec-
                                    6         retary shall consult with appropriate officials of affected Federal, State, and
                                    7         local agencies and national, regional, and local organizations. The consulta-
                                    8         tion shall include holding public hearings that the Secretary determines to
                                    9         be appropriate to provide a full opportunity for public comment.
                                  10            (c) CONTENTS       OF REPORT.—The             report shall contain the following:
                                  11                  (1) A comprehensive listing of all authorized but unacquired parcels
                                  12               of land within the exterior boundaries of each System unit as of No-
                                  13               vember 28, 1990.
                                  14                  (2) A priority listing of all those unacquired parcels by System unit
                                  15               and for the System as a whole. The list shall describe the acreage and
                                  16               ownership of each parcel, the estimated cost of acquisition for each par-
                                  17               cel (subject to any statutory acquisition limitations for the land), and
                                  18               the basis for the estimate.
                                  19                  (3) An analysis and evaluation of the current and future needs of
                                  20               each System unit for resource management, interpretation, construc-
                                  21               tion, operation and maintenance, personnel, and housing, together with
                                  22               an estimate of the costs.
                                  23          § 100506. Boundary changes to System units
                                  24            (a) CRITERIA       FOR      EVALUATION.—The Secretary shall maintain criteria
                                  25          to evaluate any proposed changes to the boundaries of System units, includ-
                                  26          ing—
                                  27                  (1) analysis of whether or not an existing boundary provides for the
                                  28               adequate protection and preservation of the natural, historic, cultural,
                                  29               scenic and recreational resources integral to the System unit;
                                  30                  (2) an evaluation of each parcel proposed for addition or deletion to
                                  31               a System unit based on the analysis under paragraph (1); and
                                  32                  (3) an assessment of the impact of potential boundary adjustments
                                  33               taking into consideration the factors in section 100505(c)(3) of this
                                  34               title and the effect of the adjustments on the local communities and
                                  35               surrounding area.
                                  36            (b) PROPOSAL           OF   SECRETARY.—In proposing a boundary change to a
                                  37          System unit, the Secretary shall—
                                  38                  (1) consult with affected agencies of State and local governments,
                                  39               surrounding communities, affected landowners, and private national,




                                  40               regional, and local organizations;
                                               HR 1068 IH

                                                                                             9
                                    1                (2) apply the criteria developed pursuant to subsection (a) and ac-
                                    2             company the proposal with a statement reflecting the results of the ap-
                                    3             plication of the criteria; and
                                    4                (3) include with the proposal an estimate of the cost for acquiring
                                    5             any parcels proposed for acquisition, the basis for the estimate, and a
                                    6             statement on the relative priority for the acquisition of each parcel
                                    7             within the priorities for acquisition of other parcels for the System unit
                                    8             and for the System.
                                    9          (c) MINOR BOUNDARY CHANGES.—
                                  10                 (1) IN      GENERAL.—When         the Secretary determines that to do so will
                                  11              contribute to, and is necessary for, the proper preservation, protection,
                                  12              interpretation, or management of a System unit, the Secretary may,
                                  13              following timely notice in writing to the Committee on Natural Re-
                                  14              sources of the House of Representatives and the Committee on Energy
                                  15              and Natural Resources of the Senate of the Secretary’s intention to do
                                  16              so, and by publication of a revised boundary map or other description
                                  17              in the Federal Register—
                                  18                         (A) make minor changes to the boundary of the System unit,
                                  19                       and amounts appropriated from the Fund shall be available for ac-
                                  20                       quisition of any land, water, and interests in land or water added
                                  21                       to the System unit by the boundary change subject to such statu-
                                  22                       tory limitations, if any, on methods of acquisition and appropria-
                                  23                       tions thereof as may be specifically applicable to the System unit;
                                  24                       and
                                  25                         (B) acquire by donation, purchase with donated funds, transfer
                                  26                       from any other Federal agency, or exchange, land, water, or inter-
                                  27                       ests in land or water adjacent to the System unit, except that in
                                  28                       exercising the Secretary’s authority under this subparagraph the
                                  29                       Secretary—
                                  30                               (i) shall not alienate property administered as part of the
                                  31                             System to acquire land by exchange;
                                  32                               (ii) shall not acquire property without the consent of the
                                  33                             owner; and
                                  34                               (iii) may acquire property owned by a State or political
                                  35                             subdivision of a State only by donation.
                                  36                 (2) CONSULTATION.—Prior to making a determination under this
                                  37              subsection, the Secretary shall consult with the governing body of the
                                  38              county, city, town, or other jurisdiction or jurisdictions having primary
                                  39              taxing authority over the land or interest to be acquired as to the im-




                                  40              pacts of the proposed action.

                                    1                (3) ACTION         TO ADVANCE LOCAL PUBLIC AWARENESS.—The                        Sec-
                                    2             retary shall take such steps as the Secretary considers appropriate to
                                    3             advance local public awareness of the proposed action.
                                    4                (4) ADMINISTRATION            OF ACQUISITIONS.—Land,              water, and interests
                                    5             in land or water acquired in accordance with this subsection shall be
                                    6             administered as part of the System unit to which they are added, sub-
                                    7             ject to the laws and regulations applicable to the System unit.
                                    8                (5) WHEN          AUTHORITY APPLIES.—For                the purposes of paragraph
                                    9             (1)(A), in all cases except the case of technical boundary changes (re-
                                  10              sulting from such causes as survey error or changed road alignments),
                                  11              the authority of the Secretary under paragraph (1)(A) shall apply only
                                  12              if each of the following conditions is met:
                                  13                         (A) The sum of the total acreage of the land, water, and inter-
                                  14                       ests in land or water to be added to the System unit and the total
                                  15                       acreage of the land, water, and interests in land or water to be
                                  16                       deleted from the System unit is not more than 5 percent of the
                                  17                       total Federal acreage authorized to be included in the System unit
                                  18                       and is less than 200 acres.
                                  19                         (B) The acquisition, if any, is not a major Federal action sig-
                                  20                       nificantly affecting the quality of the human environment, as de-
                                  21                       termined by the Secretary.
                                  22                         (C) The sum of the total appraised value of the land, water, and
                                  23                       interests in land or water to be added to the System unit and the
                                  24                       total appraised value of the land, water, and interests in land or
                                  25                       water to be deleted from the System unit does not exceed
                                  26                       $750,000.
                                  27                         (D) The proposed boundary change is not an element of a more
                                  28                       comprehensive boundary change proposal.
                                  29                         (E) The proposed boundary has been subject to a public review
                                  30                       and comment period.
                                  31                         (F) The Director obtains written consent for the boundary
                                  32                       change from all property owners whose land, water, or interests
                                  33                       in land or water, or a portion of whose land, water, or interests
                                  34                       in land or water, will be added to or deleted from the System unit
                                  35                       by the boundary change.
                                  36                         (G) The land abuts other Federal land administered by the Di-
                                  37                       rector.
                                  38                 (6) ACT         OF CONGRESS REQUIRED.—Minor                 boundary changes involv-
                                  39              ing only deletions of acreage owned by the Federal Government and ad-




                                  40              ministered by the Service may be made only by Act of Congress.

                                    1         § 100507. Additional areas for System
                                    2           (a) MONITORING AREAS                 FOR   INCLUSION        IN   SYSTEM.—The Secretary
                                    3         shall investigate, study, and continually monitor the welfare of areas whose
                                    4         resources exhibit qualities of national significance and that may have poten-
                                    5         tial for inclusion in the System.
                                    6           (b) SUBMISSION          OF   LIST   OF   AREAS RECOMMENDED             FOR     STUDY   FOR   PO-
                                    7         TENTIAL INCLUSION.—

                                    8                 (1) WHEN          LIST IS TO BE SUBMITTED.—At              the beginning of each cal-
                                    9              endar year, with the annual budget submission, the Secretary shall sub-
                                  10               mit to the Committee on Natural Resources of the House of Represent-
                                  11               atives and the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources of the
                                  12               Senate a list of areas recommended for study for potential inclusion in
                                  13               the System.
                                  14                  (2) FACTORS         TO BE CONSIDERED.—In              developing the list to be sub-
                                  15               mitted under this subsection, the Secretary shall consider—
                                  16                          (A) the areas that have the greatest potential to meet the estab-
                                  17                        lished criteria of national significance, suitability, and feasibility;
                                  18                          (B) themes, sites, and resources not already adequately rep-
                                  19                        resented in the System; and
                                  20                          (C) public petitions and Congressional resolutions.
                                  21                  (3) ACCOMPANYING              SYNOPSIS.—Accompanying             the annual listing of
                                  22               areas shall be a synopsis, for each report previously submitted, of the
                                  23               current and changed condition of the resource integrity of the area and
                                  24               other relevant factors, compiled as a result of continual periodic moni-
                                  25               toring and embracing the period since the previous submission or initial
                                  26               report submission one year earlier.

                                    1                        (B) any trail for potential addition to the national trails system.
                                    2          (c) STUDY       OF   AREAS   FOR     POTENTIAL INCLUSION.—
                                    3                (1) STUDY          TO BE COMPLETED WITHIN 3 YEARS.—The                           Secretary
                                    4             shall complete the study for each area for potential inclusion in the
                                    5             System within 3 complete fiscal years following the date on which
                                    6             funds are first made available for that purpose.
                                    7                (2) OPPORTUNITY               FOR PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT REQUIRED.—Each
                                    8             study under this section shall be prepared with appropriate opportunity
                                    9             for public involvement, including at least one public meeting in the vi-
                                  10              cinity of the area under study, and after reasonable efforts to notify
                                  11              potentially affected landowners and State and local governments.
                                  12                 (3) CONSIDERATIONS.—In conducting the study, the Secretary shall
                                  13              consider whether the area under study—
                                  14                         (A) possesses nationally significant natural or cultural resources
                                  15                       and represents one of the most important examples of a particular
                                  16                       resource type in the country; and
                                  17                         (B) is a suitable and feasible addition to the System.
                                  18                 (4) SCOPE         OF STUDY.—Each         study—
                                  19                         (A) with regard to the area being studied, shall consider—
                                  20                                (i) the rarity and integrity of the resources;
                                  21                                (ii) the threats to those resources;
                                  22                                (iii) whether similar resources are already protected in the
                                  23                            System or in other public or private ownership;
                                  24                                (iv) the public use potential;
                                  25                                (v) the interpretive and educational potential;
                                  26                                (vi) costs associated with acquisition, development, and op-
                                  27                            eration;
                                  28                                (vii) the socioeconomic impacts of any designation;
                                  29                                (viii) the level of local and general public support; and
                                  30                                (ix) whether the area is of appropriate configuration to en-
                                  31                            sure long-term resource protection and visitor use;
                                  32                         (B) shall consider whether direct Service management or alter-
                                  33                       native protection by other public agencies or the private sector is
                                  34                       appropriate for the area;
                                  35                         (C) shall identify what alternative or combination of alternatives
                                  36                       would in the professional judgment of the Director be most effec-
                                  37                       tive and efficient in protecting significant resources and providing
                                  38                       for public enjoyment; and
                                  39                         (D) may include any other information that the Secretary con-




                                  40                       siders to be relevant.

                                                                                          15
                                    1         Subchapter I—System Resource Inventory
                                    2                     and Management
                                    3         § 100701. Protection, interpretation, and research in System
                                    4           Recognizing the ever increasing societal pressures being placed upon
                                    5         America’s unique natural and cultural resources contained in the System,
                                    6         the Secretary shall continually improve the ability of the Service to provide
                                    7         state-of-the-art management, protection, and interpretation of, and research
                                    8         on, the resources of the System.
                                    9         § 100702. Research mandate
                                  10            The Secretary shall ensure that management of System units is enhanced
                                  11          by the availability and utilization of a broad program of the highest quality
                                  12          science and information.
                                  13          § 100703. Cooperative study units
                                  14            The Secretary shall enter into cooperative agreements with colleges and
                                  15          universities, including land grant schools, in partnership with other Federal
                                  16          and State agencies, to establish cooperative study units to conduct multi-
                                  17          disciplinary research and develop integrated information products on the re-
                                  18          sources of the System, or the larger region of which System units are a
                                  19          part.
                                  20          § 100704. Inventory and monitoring program
                                  21            The Secretary shall undertake a program of inventory and monitoring of
                                  22          System resources to establish baseline information and to provide informa-
                                  23          tion on the long-term trends in the condition of System resources. The mon-
                                  24          itoring program shall be developed in cooperation with other Federal moni-
                                  25          toring and information collection efforts to ensure a cost-effective approach.
                                  26          § 100705. Availability of System units for scientific study
                                  27            (a) IN GENERAL.—The Secretary may solicit, receive, and consider re-
                                  28          quests from Federal or non-Federal public or private agencies, organiza-
                                  29          tions, individuals, or other entities for the use of any System unit for pur-
                                  30          poses of scientific study.
                                  31            (b) CRITERIA.—A request for use of a System unit under subsection (a)
                                  32          may be approved only if the Secretary determines that the proposed study—
                                  33                    (1) is consistent with applicable laws and Service management poli-
                                  34                  cies; and
                                  35                    (2) will be conducted in a manner that poses no threat to the System
                                  36                  unit resources or public enjoyment derived from System unit resources.
                                  37            (c) FEE WAIVER.—The Secretary may waive any System unit admission
                                  38          or recreational use fee in order to facilitate the conduct of scientific study




                                  39          under this section.
                                                HR 1068 IH

                                                                                          16
                                    1           (d) BENEFIT-SHARING ARRANGEMENTS.—The Secretary may negotiate
                                    2         for and enter into equitable, efficient benefit-sharing arrangements with the
                                    3         research community and private industry.
                                    4         § 100706. Integration of study results into management deci-
                                    5                        sions
                                    6           The Secretary shall take such measures as are necessary to ensure the
                                    7         full and proper utilization of the results of scientific study for System unit
                                    8         management decisions. In each case in which an action undertaken by the
                                    9         Service may cause a significant adverse effect on a System unit resource,
                                  10          the administrative record shall reflect the manner in which System unit re-
                                  11          source studies have been considered. The trend in the condition of resources
                                  12          of the System shall be a significant factor in the annual performance eval-
                                  13          uation of each superintendent of a System unit.
                                  14          § 100707. Confidentiality of information
                                  15            Information concerning the nature and specific location of a System re-
                                  16          source that is endangered, threatened, rare, or commercially valuable, of
                                  17          mineral or paleontological objects within System units, or of objects of cul-
                                  18          tural patrimony within System units, may be withheld from the public in
                                  19          response to a request under section 552 of title 5 unless the Secretary de-
                                  20          termines that—
                                  21                  (1) disclosure of the information would further the purposes of the
                                  22               System unit in which the resource or object is located and would not
                                  23               create an unreasonable risk of harm, theft, or destruction of the re-
                                  24               source or object, including individual organic or inorganic specimens;
                                  25               and
                                  26                  (2) disclosure is consistent with other laws protecting the resource
                                  27               or object.
                                  28               Subchapter II—System Unit Resource
                                  29                            Protection
                                  30          § 100721. Definitions
                                  31            In this subchapter:
                                  32                  (1) DAMAGES.—The term ‘‘damages’’ includes—
                                  33                         (A) compensation for—
                                  34                               (i)(I) the cost of replacing, restoring, or acquiring the
                                  35                            equivalent of a System unit resource; and
                                  36                               (II) the value of any significant loss of use of a System
                                  37                            unit resource pending its restoration or replacement or the
                                  38                            acquisition of an equivalent resource; or
                                  39                               (ii) the value of the System unit resource if the System




                                  40                            unit resource cannot be replaced or restored; and
                                               HR 1068 IH

                                                                                           17
                                    1                         (B) the cost of a damage assessment under section 100723(b)
                                    2                       of this title.
                                    3                 (2) RESPONSE            COSTS.—The       term ‘‘response costs’’ means the costs
                                    4              of actions taken by the Secretary to—
                                    5                         (A) prevent or minimize destruction or loss of or injury to a
                                    6                       System unit resource;
                                    7                         (B) abate or minimize the imminent risk of the destruction,
                                    8                       loss, or injury; or
                                    9                         (C) monitor ongoing effects of incidents causing the destruction,
                                  10                        loss, or injury.
                                  11                  (3) SYSTEM        UNIT RESOURCE.—

                                  12                          (A) IN    GENERAL.—The           term ‘‘System unit resource’’ means any
                                  13                        living or non-living resource that is located within the boundaries
                                  14                        of a System unit.
                                  15                          (B) EXCLUSION.—The term ‘‘System unit resource’’ does not
                                  16                        include a resource owned by a non-Federal entity.
                                  17          § 100722. Liability
                                  18            (a) IN GENERAL.—Subject to subsection (c), any person that destroys,
                                  19          causes the loss of, or injures any System unit resource is liable to the
                                  20          United States for response costs and damages resulting from the destruc-
                                  21          tion, loss, or injury.
                                  22            (b) LIABILITY IN REM.—Any instrumentality, including a vessel, vehicle,
                                  23          aircraft, or other equipment, that destroys, causes the loss of, or injures any
                                  24          System unit resource shall be liable in rem to the United States for re-
                                  25          sponse costs and damages resulting from the destruction, loss, or injury to
                                  26          the same extent as a person is liable under subsection (a).
                                  27            (c) DEFENSES.—A person is not liable under this section if the person
                                  28          establishes that—
                                  29                  (1) the destruction, loss of, or injury to the System unit resource
                                  30               was caused solely by an act of God or an act of war;
                                  31                  (2) the person acted with due care, and the destruction, loss of, or
                                  32               injury to the System unit resource was caused solely by an act or omis-
                                  33               sion of a 3d party, other than an employee or agent of the person; or
                                  34                  (3) the destruction, loss, or injury to the System unit resource was
                                  35               caused by an activity authorized by Federal or State law.
                                  36            (d) SCOPE.—Liability under this section is in addition to any other liabil-
                                  37          ity that may arise under Federal or State law.
                                  38          § 100723. Actions
                                  39            (a) CIVIL ACTION             FOR   RESPONSE COSTS          AND   DAMAGES.—The Attorney




                                  40          General, on request of the Secretary after a finding by the Secretary of de-
                                  41          struction, loss, or injury to a System unit resource or a finding that absent

                                    1         the undertaking of a response action, destruction, loss, or injury to a Sys-

                                    3         States district court against any person or instrumentality that may be lia-
                                    4         ble under section 100722 of this title for response costs and damages. The
                                    5         Secretary shall submit a request for the civil action to the Attorney General
                                    6         whenever a person may be liable or an instrumentality may be liable in rem
                                    7         for those costs and damages under section 100722 of this title.
                                    8           (b) RESPONSE ACTIONS               AND   ASSESSMENT        OF   DESTRUCTION, LOSS,      OR
                                    9         INJURY.—
                                  10                  (1) ACTIONS       TO PREVENT OR MINIMIZE DESTRUCTION, LOSS, OR IN-
                                  11               JURY.—The       Secretary shall undertake all necessary actions to—
                                  12                          (A) prevent or minimize the destruction, loss of, or injury to

                                  14                          (B) minimize the imminent risk of destruction, loss, or injury

                                  18          § 100724. Use of recovered amounts
                                  19            (a) LIMITATION         ON   USE.—Response costs and damages recovered by the
                                  20          Secretary under this subchapter or amounts recovered by the Federal Gov-
                                  21          ernment under any Federal, State, or local law or regulation or otherwise

                                  24          may be used only as follows:
                                  25                  (1) REIMBURSEMENT.—To reimburse response costs and damage as-
                                  26               sessments by the Secretary or other Federal agencies as the Secretary
                                  27               considers appropriate.
                                  28                  (2) RESTORATION          AND REPLACEMENT.—To                 restore, replace, or ac-
                                  29               quire the equivalent of System unit resources that were the subject of
                                  30               the action and to monitor and study those System unit resources. The
                                  31               funds may not be used to acquire any land or water, interest in land
                                  32               or water, or right to land or water unless the acquisition is specifically
                                  33               approved in advance in appropriations Acts. The acquisition shall be
                                  34               subject to any limitations contained in the legislation establishing the
                                  35               System unit.
                                  36            (b) EXCESS AMOUNTS.—Any amounts remaining after expenditures pur-
                                  37          suant to paragraphs (1) and (2) of subsection (a) shall be deposited in the
                                  38          Treasury.

                                    3            Subchapter III—Mining Activity Within
                                    4                        System Units
                                    5         § 100731. Findings and declaration
                                    6           Congress finds and declares that—
                                    7                 (1) the level of technology of mineral exploration and development
                                    8              has changed radically, and continued application of the mining laws of
                                    9              the United States to System units to which the mining laws apply con-
                                  10               flicts with the purposes for which the System units were established;
                                  11               and
                                  12                  (2) all mining operations in System units should be conducted so as
                                  13               to prevent or minimize damage to the environment and other resource
                                  14               values.
                                  15          § 100732. Preservation and management of System units by
                                  16                         Secretary; promulgation of regulations
                                  17            To preserve for the benefit of present and future generations the pristine
                                  18          beauty of System units, and to further the purposes of section 100101(a),
                                  19          chapter 1003, and sections 100751(a), 100752, 100753, and 102101 of this
                                  20          title and the individual organic Acts for the System units, all activities re-
                                  21          sulting from the exercise of mineral rights on patented or unpatented min-
                                  22          ing claims within any System unit shall be subject to such regulations pre-
                                  23          scribed by the Secretary as the Secretary considers necessary or desirable
                                  24          for the preservation and management of the System units.
                                  25          § 100733. Recordation of mining claims; publication of no-
                                  26                         tice
                                  27            All mining claims under the Mining Law of 1872 (30 U.S.C. chapter 2,
                                  28          sections 161 and 162, and chapters 12A and 16) that lie within the bound-
                                  29          aries of System units in existence on September 28, 1976, that were not
                                  30          recorded with the Secretary within one year after September 28, 1976, shall
                                  31          be conclusively presumed to be abandoned and shall be void. The recorda-
                                  32          tion does not render valid any claim that was not valid on September 28,
                                  33          1976, or that becomes invalid after that date.
                                  34          § 100734. Report on finding or notification of potential dam-
                                  35                         age to natural and historical landmarks
                                  36            When the Secretary finds on the Secretary’s own motion or on being noti-
                                  37          fied in writing by an appropriate scientific, historical, or archeological au-
                                  38          thority that a district, site, building, structure, or object that has been
                                  39          found to be nationally significant in illustrating natural history or the his-




                                  40          tory of the United States and that has been designated as a natural or his-
                                  41          toric landmark may be irreparably lost or destroyed in whole or in part by


                                               HR 1068 IH

                                                                                           20
                                    1         any surface mining activity, including exploration for or removal or produc-
                                    2         tion of minerals or materials, the Secretary shall notify the person con-
                                    3         ducting the activity and submit a report on the findings or notification, in-
                                    4         cluding the basis for the Secretary’s finding that the activity may cause ir-
                                    5         reparable loss or destruction of a national landmark, to the Advisory Coun-
                                    6         cil on Historic Preservation, with a request for advice of the Council as to
                                    7         alternative measures that may be taken by the United States to mitigate
                                    8         or abate the activity.
                                    9         § 100735. Civil actions for just compensation by mining
                                  10                          claim holders
                                  11            The holder of any patented or unpatented mining claim subject to this
                                  12          subchapter that believes the holder has suffered a loss by operation of this
                                  13          subchapter, or by orders or regulations issued pursuant to this subchapter,
                                  14          may bring a civil action in United States district court to recover just com-
                                  15          pensation, which shall be awarded if the court finds that the loss constitutes
                                  16          a taking of property compensable under the Constitution.
                                  17          § 100736. Acquisition of land by Secretary
                                  18            Nothing in this subchapter shall be construed to limit the authority of
                                  19          the Secretary to acquire land and interests in land within the boundary of
                                  20          any System unit. The Secretary shall give prompt and careful consideration
                                  21          to any offer made by the owner of any valid right or other property in Gla-
                                  22          cier Bay National Monument, Death Valley National Monument, Organ
                                  23          Pipe Cactus National Monument, or Mount McKinley National Park to sell
                                  24          the right or other property if the owner notifies the Secretary that the con-
                                  25          tinued ownership of the right or property is causing, or would result in,
                                  26          undue hardship.

                                  24          § 100751. Regulations

                                  38          § 100752. Destruction of animals and plant life
                                  39            The Secretary may provide for the destruction of such animals and plant




                                  40          life as may be detrimental to the use of any System unit.
                                                HR 1068 IH

                                                                                          22
                                    1         § 100753. Disposal of timber
                                    2           The Secretary, on terms and conditions to be fixed by the Secretary, may
                                    3         sell or dispose of timber in cases where, in the judgment of the Secretary,
                                    4         the cutting of timber is required to control attacks of insects or diseases
                                    5         or otherwise conserve the scenery or the natural or historic objects in any
                                    6         System unit.
                                    7         § 100754. Relinquishment of legislative jurisdiction
                                    8           (a) IN GENERAL.—Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the Sec-
                                    9         retary may relinquish to a State or a territory (including a possession) of
                                  10          the United States part of the legislative jurisdiction of the United States
                                  11          over System land or interests in land in that State or territory. Relinquish-
                                  12          ment may be accomplished—
                                  13                   (1) by filing with the chief executive official of the State or territory
                                  14               a notice of relinquishment to take effect on acceptance; or
                                  15                   (2) as the laws of the State or territory may otherwise provide.
                                  16            (b) SUBMISSION         OF   AGREEMENT         TO   CONGRESS.—Prior to consummating
                                  17          a relinquishment under subsection (a), the Secretary shall submit the pro-
                                  18          posed agreement to the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources of the
                                  19          Senate and the Committee on Natural Resources of the House of Represent-
                                  20          atives. The Secretary shall not finalize the agreement until 60 calendar days
                                  21          after the submission has elapsed.
                                  22            (c) CONCURRENT LEGISLATIVE JURISDICTION.—The Secretary shall dili-
                                  23          gently pursue the consummation of arrangements with each State or terri-
                                  24          tory within which a System unit is located so that insofar as practicable the
                                  25          United States shall exercise concurrent legislative jurisdiction within System
                                  26          units.
                                  27          § 100755. Applicability of other laws
                                  28            (a) IN GENERAL.—This section and sections 100501, 100901(d) to (h),
                                  29          101302(b)(2), 101901(c), and 102711 of this title, and the various authori-
                                  30          ties relating to the administration and protection of System units, including
                                  31          the provisions of law listed in subsection (b), shall, to the extent that those
                                  32          provisions are not in conflict with any such specific provision, be applicable
                                  33          to System units, and any reference in any of these provisions to a System
                                  34          unit does not limit those provisions to that System unit.
                                  35            (b) APPLICABLE PROVISIONS.—The provisions of law referred to in sub-
                                  36          section (a) are—
                                  37                   (1) section 100101(a), chapter 1003, sections 100751(a), 100752,
                                  38               100753, 101101, 101102, 101511, 102101, 102712, 102901, 104905,
                                  39               and 104906, and chapter 2003 of this title;





                                  40                   (2) the Act of March 4, 1911 (43 U.S.C. 961); and
                                  41                   (3) chapter 3201 of this title.

                                    2         § 100901. Authority of Secretary to carry out certain activi-
                                    3                        ties
                                    4           (a) IN GENERAL.—To facilitate the administration of the System, the
                                    5         Secretary, under such terms and conditions as the Secretary may consider
                                    6         advisable, may carry out the activities described in this section.
                                    7           (b) SERVICES, RESOURCES,             OR   WATER CONTRACTS.—The Secretary may
                                    8         enter into contracts that provide for the sale or lease to persons, States,
                                    9         or political subdivisions of States, of services, resources, or water available
                                  10          within a System unit, as long as the activity does not jeopardize or unduly
                                  11          interfere with the primary natural or historic resource of the System unit,
                                  12          if the person, State, or political subdivision—
                                  13                  (1) provides public accommodations or services within the immediate
                                  14               vicinity of the System unit to individuals visiting the System unit; and
                                  15                  (2) demonstrates to the Secretary that there are no reasonable alter-
                                  16               natives by which to acquire or perform the necessary services, re-
                                  17               sources, or water.
                                  18            (c) VEHICULAR AIR CONDITIONING.—The Secretary may acquire, and
                                  19          have installed, air conditioning units for any Government-owned passenger
                                  20          motor vehicles used by the Service, where assigned duties necessitate long
                                  21          periods in automobiles or in regions of the United States where high tem-
                                  22          peratures and humidity are common and prolonged.
                                  23            (d) UTILITY FACILITIES.—The Secretary may erect and maintain fire
                                  24          protection facilities, water lines, telephone lines, electric lines, and other
                                  25          utility facilities adjacent to any System unit, where necessary, to provide
                                  26          service in the System unit.
                                  27            (e) SUPPLIES        AND   RENTAL     OF   EQUIPMENT.—The Secretary may furnish,
                                  28          on a reimbursement of appropriation basis, supplies, and rent equipment,
                                  29          to persons and agencies that, in cooperation with and subject to the ap-
                                  30          proval of the Secretary, render services or perform functions that facilitate
                                  31          or supplement the activities of the Department of the Interior in the admin-
                                  32          istration of the System. The reimbursements may be credited to the appro-
                                  33          priation current at the time reimbursements are received.
                                  34            (f) CONTRACTS          FOR   UTILITY FACILITIES.—The Secretary may contract,




                                  35          under terms and conditions that the Secretary considers to be in the inter-
                                  36          est of the Federal Government, for the sale, operation, maintenance, repair,


                                                HR 1068 IH

                                                                                           24
                                    1         or relocation of Government-owned electric and telephone lines and other
                                    2         utility facilities used for the administration and protection of the System,
                                    3         regardless of whether the lines and facilities are located within or outside
                                    4         the System.
                                    5           (g) RIGHTS       OF     WAY NECESSARY TO CONSTRUCT, IMPROVE,                       AND   MAIN-
                                    6         TAIN   ROADS.—The Secretary may acquire—
                                    7                  (1) rights of way necessary to construct, improve, and maintain
                                    8                roads within the authorized boundaries of any System unit; and
                                    9                  (2) land and interests in land adjacent to the rights of way, when—
                                  10                          (A) considered necessary by the Secretary—
                                  11                                (i) to provide adequate protection of natural features; or
                                  12                                (ii) to avoid traffic and other hazards resulting from pri-
                                  13                             vate road access connections; or
                                  14                          (B) the acquisition of adjacent residual tracts, which otherwise
                                  15                        would remain after acquiring the rights of way, would be in the
                                  16                        public interest.
                                  17            (h) OPERATION            AND   MAINTENANCE           OF    MOTOR      AND      OTHER EQUIP-
                                  18          MENT.—

                                  19                   (1) IN    GENERAL.—The          Secretary may operate, repair, maintain, and

                                  21                 equipment is used on Federal projects of the System, chargeable to
                                  22                 other appropriations, or on work of other Federal agencies, when re-

                                  29                          (B) credited to appropriations currently available at the time
                                  30                        adjustment is effected.
                                  31                   (3) RENTAL        OF EQUIPMENT FOR FIRE CONTROL PURPOSES.—The
                                  32                 Secretary may rent equipment for fire control purposes to State, coun-
                                  33                 ty, private, or other non-Federal agencies that cooperate with the Sec-
                                  34                 retary in the administration of the System and other areas in fire con-
                                  35                 trol. The rental shall be under the terms of written cooperative agree-
                                  36                 ments. The amount collected for the rentals shall be credited to appro-
                                  37                 priations currently available at the time payment is received.

                                  14              section shall be for—
                                  15                         (A) the ground occupied by the canals, ditches, flumes, tunnels,
                                  16                       reservoirs, or other water conduits or water plants, or electrical or
                                  17                       other works permitted under paragraph (1); and

                                  21                            lines, electrical, telegraph, and telephone lines and poles.

                                  25              the public interest.
