                                  22          § 101914. Term of concession contracts
                                  23            A concession contract entered into pursuant to this subchapter shall gen-
                                  24          erally be awarded for a term of 10 years or less. The Secretary may award
                                  25          a contract for a term of up to 20 years if the Secretary determines that
                                  26          the contract terms and conditions, including the required construction of
                                  27          capital improvements, warrant a longer term.
                                  28          § 101915. Protection of concessioner investment
                                  29            (a) DEFINITIONS.—In this section:
                                  30                  (1) CAPITAL           IMPROVEMENT.—The               term ‘‘capital improvement’’
                                  31               means a structure, a fixture, or nonremovable equipment provided by
                                  32               a concessioner pursuant to the terms of a concession contract and lo-
                                  33               cated on land of the United States within a System unit.
                                  34                  (2) CONSUMER           PRICE INDEX.—The              term ‘‘Consumer Price Index’’
                                  35               means—
                                  36                          (A) the ‘‘Consumer Price Index—All Urban Consumers’’ pub-
                                  37                        lished by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of
                                  38                        Labor; or
                                  39                          (B) if the Index is not published, another regularly published




                                  40                        cost-of-living index approximating the Consumer Price Index.
                                               HR 1068 IH

                                    1           (b) LEASEHOLD SURRENDER INTEREST          60              IN   CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS.—
                                    2         A concessioner that constructs a capital improvement on land owned by the
                                    3         United States within a System unit pursuant to a concession contract shall
                                    4         have a leasehold surrender interest in the capital improvement subject to
                                    5         the following terms and conditions:
                                    6                 (1) IN     GENERAL.—A         concessioner shall have a leasehold surrender
                                    7              interest in each capital improvement constructed by a concessioner
                                    8              under a concession contract, consisting solely of a right to compensa-
                                    9              tion for the capital improvement to the extent of the value of the con-
                                  10               cessioner’s leasehold surrender interest in the capital improvement.
                                  11                  (2) PLEDGE        AS SECURITY.—A             leasehold surrender interest may be
                                  12               pledged as security for financing of a capital improvement or the acqui-
                                  13               sition of a concession contract when approved by the Secretary pursu-
                                  14               ant to this subchapter.
                                  15                  (3) TRANSFER         AND RELINQUISHMENT OR WAIVER OF INTEREST.—
                                  16               A leasehold surrender interest shall be transferred by the concessioner
                                  17               in connection with any transfer of the concession contract and may be
                                  18               relinquished or waived by the concessioner.
                                  19                  (4) LIMIT        ON EXTINGUISHING OR TAKING INTEREST.—A                         leasehold
                                  20               surrender interest shall not be extinguished by the expiration or other
                                  21               termination of a concession contract and may not be taken for public
                                  22               use except on payment of just compensation.
                                  23                  (5) VALUE        OF INTEREST.—The            value of a leasehold surrender inter-
                                  24               est in a capital improvement shall be an amount equal to the initial
                                  25               value (construction cost of the capital improvement), increased (or de-
                                  26               creased) by the same percentage increase (or decrease) as the percent-
                                  27               age increase (or decrease) in the Consumer Price Index, from the date
                                  28               of making the investment in the capital improvement by the conces-
                                  29               sioner to the date of payment of the value of the leasehold surrender
                                  30               interest, less depreciation of the capital improvement as evidenced by
                                  31               the condition and prospective serviceability in comparison with a new
                                  32               unit of like kind.
                                  33                  (6) VALUE         OF   INTEREST         IN    CERTAIN      NEW     CONCESSION       CON-
                                  34               TRACTS.—
                                  35                          (A) HOW     VALUE IS DETERMINED.—The                 Secretary may provide,
                                  36                        in any new concession contract that the Secretary estimates will
                                  37                        have a leasehold surrender interest of more than $10,000,000,
                                  38                        that the value of any leasehold surrender interest in a capital im-
                                  39                        provement shall be based on—





                                  40                               (i) a reduction on an annual basis, in equal portions, over
                                  41                            the same number of years as the time period associated with

                                    1                           the straight line depreciation of the initial value (construction
                                    2                           cost of the capital improvement), as provided by applicable
                                    3                           Federal income tax laws and regulations in effect on Novem-
                                    4                           ber 12, 1998; or
                                    5                              (ii) an alternative formula that is consistent with the objec-
                                    6                           tives of this subchapter.
                                    7                        (B) WHEN       ALTERNATIVE FORMULA MAY BE USED.—The                      Sec-

                                    9                      only if the Secretary determines, after scrutiny of the financial

                                    1           (e) TITLE      TO      IMPROVEMENTS.—Title to any capital improvement con-

                                    4         § 101916. Reasonableness of rates and charges
                                    5           (a) IN GENERAL.—A concession contract shall permit the concessioner to
                                    6         set reasonable and appropriate rates and charges for facilities, goods, and
                                    7         services provided to the public, subject to approval under subsection (b).
                                    8           (b) APPROVAL        BY   SECRETARY REQUIRED.—
                                    9                 (1) FACTORS         TO CONSIDER.—A           concessioner’s rates and charges to
                                  10               the public shall be subject to approval by the Secretary. The approval
                                  11               process utilized by the Secretary shall be as prompt and as
                                  12               unburdensome to the concessioner as possible and shall rely on market
                                  13               forces to establish reasonableness of rates and charges to the maximum
                                  14               extent practicable. The Secretary shall approve rates and charges that
                                  15               the Secretary determines to be reasonable and appropriate. Unless oth-
                                  16               erwise provided in the concession contract, the reasonableness and ap-
                                  17               propriateness of rates and charges shall be determined primarily by
                                  18               comparison with those rates and charges for facilities, goods, and serv-
                                  19               ices of comparable character under similar conditions, with due consid-
                                  20               eration to the following factors and other factors deemed relevant by
                                  21               the Secretary:
                                  22                         (A) Length of season.
                                  23                         (B) Peakloads.
                                  24                         (C) Average percentage of occupancy.
                                  25                         (D) Accessibility.
                                  26                         (E) Availability and costs of labor and materials.
                                  27                         (F) Type of patronage.
                                  28                  (2) RATES         AND CHARGES NOT TO EXCEED MARKET RATES AND
                                  29               CHARGES.—Rates            and charges may not exceed the market rates and
                                  30               charges for comparable facilities, goods, and services, after taking into
                                  31               account the factors referred to in paragraph (1).
                                  32            (c) IMPLEMENTATION            OF    RECOMMENDATIONS.—Not later than 6 months
                                  33          after receiving recommendations from the Advisory Board regarding conces-
                                  34          sioner rates and charges to the public, the Secretary shall implement the
                                  35          recommendations or report to Congress the reasons for not implementing
                                  36          the recommendations.
                                  37          § 101917. Franchise fees
                                  38            (a) IN GENERAL.—A concession contract shall provide for payment to the
                                  39          Federal Government of a franchise fee or other monetary consideration as




                                  40          determined by the Secretary, on consideration of the probable value to the
                                  41          concessioner of the privileges granted by the particular contract involved.


                                               HR 1068 IH

                                                                                          64
                                    1         Probable value shall be based on a reasonable opportunity for net profit in
                                    2         relation to capital invested and the obligations of the concession contract.
                                    3         Consideration of revenue to the United States shall be subordinate to the
                                    4         objectives of protecting and preserving System units and of providing nec-
                                    5         essary and appropriate services for visitors at reasonable rates.
                                    6           (b) PROVISIONS TO BE SPECIFIED                   IN   CONTRACT.—The amount of the
                                    7         franchise fee or other monetary consideration paid to the United States for
                                    8         the term of the concession contract shall be specified in the concession con-
                                    9         tract and may be modified only to reflect extraordinary unanticipated
                                  10          changes from the conditions anticipated as of the effective date of the con-
                                  11          cession contract. The Secretary shall include in concession contracts with a
                                  12          term of more than 5 years a provision that allows reconsideration of the
                                  13          franchise fee at the request of the Secretary or the concessioner in the event
                                  14          of extraordinary unanticipated changes. The provision shall provide for
                                  15          binding arbitration in the event that the Secretary and the concessioner are
                                  16          unable to agree on an adjustment to the franchise fee in those cir-
                                  17          cumstances.
                                  18            (c) SPECIAL ACCOUNT           IN   TREASURY.—
                                  19                  (1) DEPOSIT       AND AVAILABILITY.—All             franchise fees (and other mon-
                                  20               etary consideration) paid to the United States pursuant to concession
                                  21               contracts shall be deposited in a special account established in the
                                  22               Treasury. Twenty percent of the funds deposited in the special account
                                  23               shall be available for expenditure by the Secretary, without further ap-
                                  24               propriation, to support activities throughout the System regardless of
                                  25               the System unit in which the funds were collected. The funds deposited
                                  26               in the special account shall remain available until expended.
                                  27                  (2) SUBACCOUNT          FOR EACH SYSTEM UNIT.—There                     shall be estab-
                                  28               lished within the special account a subaccount for each System unit.
                                  29               Each subaccount shall be credited with 80 percent of the franchise fees
                                  30               (and other monetary consideration) collected at a single System unit
                                  31               under concession contracts. The funds credited to the subaccount for
                                  32               a System unit shall be available for expenditure by the Secretary, with-
                                  33               out further appropriation, for use at the System unit for visitor services
                                  34               and for purposes of funding high-priority and urgently necessary re-
                                  35               source management programs and operations. The funds credited to a
                                  36               subaccount shall remain available until expended.
                                  37          § 101918. Transfer or conveyance of concession contracts or
                                  38                         leasehold surrender interests
                                  39            (a) APPROVAL       OF    SECRETARY.—No concession contract or leasehold sur-




                                  40          render interest may be transferred, assigned, sold, or otherwise conveyed or
                                               HR 1068 IH

                                                                                           65
                                    1         pledged by a concessioner without prior written notification to, and approval
                                    2         by, the Secretary.
                                    3           (b) CONDITIONS.—The Secretary shall approve a transfer or conveyance
                                    4         described in subsection (a) unless the Secretary finds that—
                                    5                 (1) the individual, corporation, or other entity seeking to acquire a
                                    6              concession contract is not qualified or able to satisfy the terms and
                                    7              conditions of the concession contract;
                                    8                 (2) the transfer or conveyance would have an adverse impact on—
                                    9                         (A) the protection, conservation, or preservation of the resources
                                  10                        of the System unit; or
                                  11                          (B) the provision of necessary and appropriate facilities and
                                  12                        services to visitors at reasonable rates and charges; and
                                  13                  (3) the terms of the transfer or conveyance are likely, directly or in-
                                  14               directly, to—
                                  15                          (A) reduce the concessioner’s opportunity for a reasonable profit
                                  16                        over the remaining term of the concession contract;
                                  17                          (B) adversely affect the quality of facilities and services pro-
                                  18                        vided by the concessioner; or
                                  19                          (C) result in a need for increased rates and charges to the pub-
                                  20                        lic to maintain the quality of the facilities and services.
                                  21            (c) MODIFICATION          OR   RENEGOTIATION          OF    TERMS.—The terms and con-
                                  22          ditions of any concession contract under this section shall not be subject to
                                  23          modification or open to renegotiation by the Secretary because of a transfer
                                  24          or conveyance described in subsection (a) unless the transfer or conveyance
                                  25          would have an adverse impact as described in subsection (b)(2).
                                  26          § 101919. National Park Service Concessions Management
                                  27                          Advisory Board
                                  28            (a) ESTABLISHMENT             AND    PURPOSE.—There is a National Park Service
                                  29          Concessions Management Advisory Board whose purpose shall be to advise
                                  30          the Secretary and Service on matters relating to management of concessions
                                  31          in the System.
                                  32            (b) DUTIES.—
                                  33                  (1) ADVICE.—The Advisory Board shall advise on each of the fol-
                                  34               lowing:
                                  35                          (A) Policies and procedures intended to ensure that services and
                                  36                        facilities provided by concessioners—
                                  37                                (i) are necessary and appropriate;
                                  38                                (ii) meet acceptable standards at reasonable rates with a
                                  39                             minimum of impact on System unit resources and values; and





                                  40                                (iii) provide the concessioners with a reasonable oppor-
                                  41                             tunity to make a profit.


                                               HR 1068 IH

                                                                                           66
                                    1                         (B) Ways to make Service concession programs and procedures
                                    2                       more cost effective, more process efficient, less burdensome, and
                                    3                       timelier.
                                    4                 (2) RECOMMENDATIONS.—The Advisory Board shall make rec-
                                    5              ommendations to the Secretary regarding each of the following:
                                    6                         (A) The Service contracting with the private sector to conduct
                                    7                       appropriate elements of concession management.
                                    8                         (B) Ways to make the review or approval of concessioner rates
                                    9                       and charges to the public more efficient, less burdensome, and
                                  10                        timelier.
                                  11                          (C) The nature and scope of products that qualify as Indian,
                                  12                        Alaska Native, and Native Hawaiian handicrafts within the mean-
                                  13                        ing of this subchapter.
                                  14                          (D) The allocation of concession fees.
                                  15                  (3) ANNUAL         REPORT.—The           Advisory Board shall provide an annual
                                  16               report on its activities to the Committee on Natural Resources of the
                                  17               House of Representatives and the Committee on Energy and Natural
                                  18               Resources of the Senate.
                                  19            (c) ADVISORY BOARD MEMBERSHIP.—Members of the Advisory Board
                                  20          shall be appointed on a staggered basis by the Secretary for a term not to
                                  21          exceed 4 years and shall serve at the pleasure of the Secretary. The Advi-
                                  22          sory Board shall be comprised of not more than 7 individuals appointed
                                  23          from among citizens of the United States not in the employment of the Fed-
                                  24          eral Government and not in the employment of or having an interest in a
                                  25          Service concession. Of the 7 members of the Advisory Board—
                                  26                  (1) one member shall be privately employed in the hospitality indus-
                                  27               try and have both broad knowledge of hotel or food service manage-
                                  28               ment and experience in the parks and recreation concession business;
                                  29                  (2) one member shall be privately employed in the tourism industry;
                                  30                  (3) one member shall be privately employed in the accounting indus-
                                  31               try;
                                  32                  (4) one member shall be privately employed in the outfitting and
                                  33               guide industry;
                                  34                  (5) one member shall be a State government employee with expertise
                                  35               in park concession management;
                                  36                  (6) one member shall be active in promotion of traditional arts and
                                  37               crafts; and
                                  38                  (7) one member shall be active in a nonprofit conservation organiza-
                                  39               tion involved in parks and recreation programs.





                                  40            (d) SERVICE        ON   ADVISORY BOARD.—Service of an individual as a mem-
                                  41          ber of the Advisory Board shall not be deemed to be service or employment


                                               HR 1068 IH

                                    1         bringing the individual within the provisions of any Federal law relating to
                                    2         conflicts of interest or otherwise imposing restrictions, requirements, or pen-

                                    5         proceedings, or matters involving the United States. Service as a member

                                    5         § 101921. Multiple contracts within a System unit
                                    6           If multiple concession contracts are awarded to authorize concessioners
                                    7         to provide the same or similar outfitting, guiding, river running, or other
                                    8         similar services at the same approximate location or resource within a Sys-
                                    9         tem unit, the Secretary shall establish a comparable franchise fee structure
                                  10          for those contracts or similar contracts, except that the terms and condi-
                                  11          tions of any existing concession contract shall not be subject to modification
                                  12          or open to renegotiation by the Secretary because of an award of a new con-
                                  13          tract at the same approximate location or resource.
                                  14          § 101922. Use of nonmonetary consideration in concession
                                  15                         contracts
                                  16            Section 1302 of title 40 shall not apply to concession contracts awarded
                                  17          by the Secretary pursuant to this subchapter.
                                  18          § 101923. Recordkeeping requirements
                                  19            (a) IN GENERAL.—A concessioner and any subconcessioner shall keep
                                  20          such records as the Secretary may prescribe to enable the Secretary to de-
                                  21          termine that all terms of a concession contract have been and are being
                                  22          faithfully performed. The Secretary and any authorized representative of the
                                  23          Secretary shall, for the purpose of audit and examination, have access to
                                  24          those records and to other records of the concessioner or subconcessioner
                                  25          pertinent to the concession contract and all terms and conditions of the con-
                                  26          cession contract.
                                  27            (b) ACCESS      TO     RECORDS     BY   COMPTROLLER GENERAL.—The Comptroller
                                  28          General and any authorized representative of the Comptroller General shall,
                                  29          until the expiration of 5 calendar years after the close of the business year
                                  30          of each concessioner or subconcessioner, have access to and the right to ex-
                                  31          amine any pertinent records described in subsection (a) of the concessioner
                                  32          or subconcessioner related to the contract involved.
                                  33          § 101924. Promotion of sale of Indian, Alaska Native, Native
                                  34                         Samoan, and Native Hawaiian handicrafts
                                  35            (a) IN GENERAL.—Promoting the sale of authentic United States Indian,
                                  36          Alaskan Native, Native Samoan, and Native Hawaiian handicrafts relating
                                  37          to the cultural, historical, and geographic characteristics of System units is
                                  38          encouraged, and the Secretary shall ensure that there is a continuing effort
                                  39          to enhance the handicraft trade where it exists and establish the trade in




                                  40          appropriate areas where the trade does not exist.
                                                HR 1068 IH

                                                                                           69
                                    1           (b) EXEMPTION FROM FRANCHISE FEE.—In furtherance of the purposes
                                    2         of subsection (a), the revenue derived from the sale of United States Indian,
                                    3         Alaska Native, Native Samoan, and Native Hawaiian handicrafts shall be
                                    4         exempt from any franchise fee payments under this subchapter.
                                    5         § 101925. Commercial use authorizations
                                    6           (a) IN GENERAL.—To the extent specified in this section, the Secretary,
                                    7         on request, may authorize a private person, corporation, or other entity to
                                    8         provide services to visitors to System units through a commercial use au-
                                    9         thorization. A commercial use authorization shall not be considered to be
                                  10          a concession contract under this subchapter and no other section of this
                                  11          subchapter shall be applicable to a commercial use authorization except
                                  12          where expressly stated.
                                  13            (b) CRITERIA        FOR    ISSUANCE      OF    COMMERCIAL USE AUTHORIZATIONS.—
                                  14                  (1) REQUIRED         DETERMINATIONS.—The               authority of this section may
                                  15               be used only to authorize provision of services that the Secretary deter-
                                  16               mines—
                                  17                          (A) will have minimal impact on resources and values of a Sys-
                                  18                        tem unit; and
                                  19                          (B) are consistent with the purpose for which the System unit
                                  20                        was established and with all applicable management plans and
                                  21                        Service policies and regulations.
                                  22                  (2) ELEMENTS           OF COMMERCIAL USE AUTHORIZATION.—The                      Sec-
                                  23               retary shall—
                                  24                          (A) require payment of a reasonable fee for issuance of a com-
                                  25                        mercial use authorization, the fees to remain available without fur-
                                  26                        ther appropriation to be used, at a minimum, to recover associated
                                  27                        management and administrative costs;
                                  28                          (B) require that the provision of services under a commercial
                                  29                        use authorization be accomplished in a manner consistent to the
                                  30                        highest practicable degree with the preservation and conservation
                                  31                        of System unit resources and values;
                                  32                          (C) take appropriate steps to limit the liability of the United
                                  33                        States arising from the provision of services under a commercial
                                  34                        use authorization;
                                  35                          (D) have no authority under this section to issue more commer-
                                  36                        cial use authorizations than are consistent with the preservation
                                  37                        and proper management of System unit resources and values; and
                                  38                          (E) shall establish other conditions for issuance of a commercial
                                  39                        use authorization that the Secretary determines to be appropriate




                                  40                        for the protection of visitors, provision of adequate and appro-
                                               HR 1068 IH

                                                                                          70
                                    1                       priate visitor services, and protection and proper management of
                                    2                       System unit resources and values.
                                    3           (c) LIMITATIONS.—Any commercial use authorization shall be limited
                                    4         to—
                                    5                 (1) commercial operations with annual gross receipts of not more
                                    6               than $25,000 resulting from services originating and provided solely
                                    7               within a System unit pursuant to the commercial use authorization;
                                    8                 (2) the incidental use of resources of the System unit by commercial
                                    9               operations that provide services originating and terminating outside the
                                  10                boundaries of the System unit; or
                                  11                  (3)(A) uses by organized children’s camps, outdoor clubs, and non-
                                  12                profit institutions (including back country use); and
                                  13                  (B) other uses, as the Secretary determines to be appropriate.
                                  14            (d) NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS.—Nonprofit institutions are not required
                                  15          to obtain commercial use authorizations unless taxable income is derived by
                                  16          the institution from the authorized use.
                                  17            (e) PROHIBITION          ON   CONSTRUCTION.—A commercial use authorization
                                  18          shall not provide for the construction of any structure, fixture, or improve-
                                  19          ment on federally-owned land within the boundaries of a System unit.
                                  20            (f) DURATION.—The term of any commercial use authorization shall not
                                  21          exceed 2 years. No preferential right of renewal or similar provisions for re-
                                  22          newal shall be granted by the Secretary.
                                  23            (g) OTHER CONTRACTS.—A person, corporation, or other entity seeking
                                  24          or obtaining a commercial use authorization shall not be precluded from
                                  25          submitting a proposal for concession contracts.
                                  26          § 101926. Regulations
                                  27            (a) IN GENERAL.—The Secretary shall prescribe regulations appropriate
                                  28          for the implementation of this subchapter.
                                  29            (b) CONTENTS.—The regulations—
                                  30                  (1) shall include appropriate provisions to ensure that concession
                                  31                services and facilities to be provided in a System unit are not seg-
                                  32                mented or otherwise split into separate concession contracts for the
                                  33                purposes of seeking to reduce anticipated annual gross receipts of a
                                  34                concession contract below $500,000; and
                                  35                  (2) shall further define the term ‘‘United States Indian, Alaskan Na-
                                  36                tive, and Native Hawaiian handicrafts’’ for the purposes of this sub-
                                  37                chapter.

                                  21          § 102102. Authority of Secretary to enter into lease for
                                  22                         buildings and associated property
                                  23            (a) IN GENERAL.—To facilitate the administration of the System, the
                                  24          Secretary, under such terms and conditions as the Secretary may consider
                                  25          advisable, and except as provided in subsection (b) and subject to subsection
                                  26          (c), may enter into a lease with any person or government entity for the
                                  27          use of buildings and associated property administered by the Secretary as
                                  28          part of the System.
                                  29            (b) PROHIBITED ACTIVITIES.—The Secretary may not use a lease under
                                  30          subsection (a) to authorize the lessee to engage in activities that are subject
                                  31          to authorization by the Secretary through a concession contract, commercial
                                  32          use authorization, or similar instrument.
                                  33            (c) USE.—Buildings and associated property leased under subsection
                                  34          (a)—
                                  35                  (1) shall be used for an activity that is consistent with the purposes
                                  36               established by law for the System unit in which the building is located;
                                  37                  (2) shall not result in degradation of the purposes and values of the
                                  38               System unit; and
                                  39                  (3) shall be compatible with Service programs.

                                  24            (a) DEFINITION.—In this section, the term ‘‘Board’’ means the National
                                  25          Park System Advisory Board established under subsection (b).
                                  26            (b) ESTABLISHMENT             AND      PURPOSE.—There is established a National

                                  37                   (2) COMPOSITION.—The Board shall be composed of no more than
                                  38               12 persons, appointed from among citizens of the United States having
                                  39               a demonstrated commitment to the mission of the Service. Board mem-




                                  40               bers shall be selected to represent various geographic regions, including
                                  41               each of the administrative regions of the Service. At least 6 of the


                                                HR 1068 IH

                                                                                         75
                                    1             members shall have outstanding expertise in one or more of the fol-
                                    2             lowing fields: history, archeology, anthropology, historical or landscape
                                    3             architecture, biology, ecology, geology, marine science, or social science.
                                    4             At least 4 of the members shall have outstanding expertise and prior
                                    5             experience in the management of national or State parks or protected
                                    6             areas, or natural or cultural resources management. The remaining
                                    7             members shall have outstanding expertise in one or more of the areas
                                    8             described above or in another professional or scientific discipline, such
                                    9             as financial management, recreation use management, land use plan-
                                  10              ning, or business management, important to the mission of the Service.
                                  11              At least one individual shall be a locally elected official from an area
                                  12              adjacent to a park.
                                  13                 (3) FIRST        MEETING.—The       Board shall hold its 1st meeting no later
                                  14              than 60 days after the date on which all members of the Board who
                                  15              are to be appointed have been appointed.
                                  16                 (4) VACANCY.—Any vacancy in the Board shall not affect its powers,
                                  17              but shall be filled in the same manner in which the original appoint-
                                  18              ment was made.
                                  19                 (5) COMPENSATION.—All members of the Board shall be reimbursed
                                  20              for travel and per diem in lieu of subsistence expenses during the per-
                                  21              formance of duties of the Board while away from home or their regular
                                  22              place of business, in accordance with subchapter I of chapter 57 of title
                                  23              5. With the exception of travel and per diem, a member of the Board
                                  24              who otherwise is an officer or employee of the United States Govern-
                                  25              ment shall serve on the Board without additional compensation.
                                  26           (d) DUTIES      AND     POWERS     OF   BOARD.—
                                  27                 (1) ADOPT        RULES.—The       Board may adopt such rules as may be nec-
                                  28              essary to establish its procedures and to govern the manner of its oper-
                                  29              ations, organization, and personnel.
                                  30                 (2) ADVICE        AND RECOMMENDATIONS.—The                   Board shall advise the
                                  31              Secretary on matters relating to the System, to other related areas,
                                  32              and to the administration of chapter 3201 of this title, including mat-

                                  34              be required to provide recommendations as to the suitability or desir-

                                  40              in making the recommendations.

                                  26      Sec.                    Chapter 1025—Museums
                                          102501.      Purpose.
                                          102502.      Definition of museum object.
                                          102503.      Authority of Secretary.
                                          102504.      Review and approval.

                                  27          § 102501. Purpose
                                  28            The purpose of this chapter is to increase the public benefits from muse-
                                  29          ums established within System units as a means of informing the public
                                  30          concerning the areas and preserving valuable objects and relics relating to
                                  31          the areas.
                                  32          § 102502. Definition of museum object
                                  33            In this chapter:
                                  34                   (1) IN    GENERAL.—The           term ‘‘museum object’’ means an object
                                  35               that—





                                  36                         (A) typically is movable; and




                                               HR 1068 IH

                                                                                             78
                                    1                         (B) is eligible to be, or is made part of, a museum, library, or
                                    2                       archive      collection     through       a      formal     procedure,       such   as
                                    3                       accessioning.
                                    4                 (2) INCLUSIONS.—The term ‘‘museum object’’ includes a prehistoric
                                    5              or historic artifact, work of art, book, document, photograph, or nat-
                                    6              ural history specimen.
                                    7         § 102503. Authority of Secretary
                                    8           (a) IN GENERAL.—Notwithstanding other provisions or limitations of law,
                                    9         the Secretary may perform the functions described in this section in the
                                  10          manner that the Secretary considers to be in the public interest.
                                  11            (b) DONATIONS            AND   BEQUESTS.—The Secretary may accept donations
                                  12          and bequests of money or other personal property, and hold, use, expend,
                                  13          and administer the money or other personal property for purposes of this
                                  14          chapter.
                                  15            (c) PURCHASES.—The Secretary may purchase museum objects and other
                                  16          personal property at prices that the Secretary considers to be reasonable.
                                  17            (d) EXCHANGES.—The Secretary may make exchanges by accepting mu-
                                  18          seum objects and other personal property and by granting in exchange for
                                  19          the museum objects or other personal property museum property under the
                                  20          administrative jurisdiction of the Secretary that no longer is needed or that
                                  21          may be held in duplicate among the museum properties administered by the
                                  22          Secretary. Exchanges shall be consummated on a basis that the Secretary
                                  23          considers to be equitable and in the public interest.
                                  24            (e) ACCEPTANCE            OF   LOANS      OF     PROPERTY.—The Secretary may accept
                                  25          the loan of museum objects and other personal property and pay transpor-
                                  26          tation costs incidental to the museum objects or other personal property.
                                  27          Loans shall be accepted on terms and conditions that the Secretary con-
                                  28          siders necessary.
                                  29            (f) LOANS       OF    PROPERTY.—The Secretary may loan to responsible public
                                  30          or private organizations, institutions, or agencies, without cost to the United
                                  31          States, such museum objects and other personal property as the Secretary
                                  32          shall consider advisable. Loans shall be made on terms and conditions that
                                  33          the Secretary considers necessary to protect the public interest in those
                                  34          properties.
                                  35            (g) TRANSFER            OF   MUSEUM OBJECTS.—The Secretary may transfer mu-
                                  36          seum objects that the Secretary determines are no longer needed for mu-
                                  37          seum purposes to qualified Federal agencies, including the Smithsonian In-
                                  38          stitution, that have programs to preserve and interpret cultural or natural
                                  39          heritage, and accept the transfer of museum objects for the purposes of this




                                  40          chapter from any other Federal agency, without reimbursement. The head
                                  41          of any other Federal agency may transfer, without reimbursement, museum


                                                HR 1068 IH

                                                                                           79
                                    1         objects directly to the administrative jurisdiction of the Secretary for the
                                    2         purpose of this chapter.
                                    3           (h) CONVEYANCE           OF   MUSEUM OBJECTS.—The Secretary may convey mu-
                                    4         seum objects that the Secretary determines are no longer needed for mu-
                                    5         seum purposes, without monetary consideration but subject to such terms
                                    6         and conditions as the Secretary considers necessary, to private institutions
                                    7         exempt from Federal taxation under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Rev-
                                    8         enue Code of 1986 (26 U.S.C. 501(c)(3)) and to non-Federal governmental
                                    9         entities if the Secretary determines that the recipient is dedicated to the
                                  10          preservation and interpretation of natural or cultural heritage and is quali-
                                  11          fied to manage the property, prior to any conveyance under this subsection
                                  12          and subsection (g).
                                  13            (i) DESTRUCTION          OF   MUSEUM OBJECTS.—The Secretary may destroy or
                                  14          cause to be destroyed museum objects that the Secretary determines to have
                                  15          no scientific, cultural, historic, educational, esthetic, or monetary value.
                                  16          § 102504. Review and approval
                                  17            The Secretary shall ensure that museum objects are treated in a careful
                                  18          and deliberate manner that protects the public interest. Prior to taking any
                                  19          action under subsection (g), (h), or (i) of section 102503 of this title, the
                                  20          Secretary shall establish a systematic review and approval process, including
                                  21          consultation with appropriate experts, that meets the highest standards of
                                  22          the museum profession for all actions taken under those subsections.

                                    7         § 102702. Crime prevention assistance
                                    8           (a) RECOMMENDATIONS                FOR   IMPROVEMENT.—The Secretary shall direct
                                    9         the chief official responsible for law enforcement within the Service to—
                                  10                  (1) compile a list of System units with the highest rates of violent
                                  11               crime;
                                  12                  (2) make recommendations concerning capital improvements, and
                                  13               other measures, needed within the System to reduce the rates of violent
                                  14               crime, including the rate of sexual assault; and
                                  15                  (3) publish the information required by paragraphs (1) and (2) in
                                  16               the Federal Register.
                                  17            (b) DISTRIBUTION          OF   FUNDS.—Based on the recommendations and list
                                  18          issued pursuant to subsection (a), the Secretary shall distribute the funds
                                  19          authorized by subsection (d) throughout the System. Priority shall be given
                                  20          to areas with the highest rates of sexual assault.
                                  21            (c) USE     OF   FUNDS.—Funds provided under this section may be used—
                                  22                  (1) to increase lighting within or adjacent to System units;
                                  23                  (2) to provide emergency phone lines to contact law enforcement or
                                  24               security personnel in areas within or adjacent to System units;
                                  25                  (3) to increase security or law enforcement personnel within or adja-
                                  26               cent to System units; or
                                  27                  (4) for any other project intended to increase the security and safety
                                  28               of System units.
                                  29            (d) AUTHORIZATION          OF      APPROPRIATIONS.—There is authorized to be ap-
                                  30          propriated out of the Violent Crime Reduction Trust Fund not more than
                                  31          $10,000,000 for the Secretary to take all necessary actions to seek to re-
                                  32          duce the incidence of violent crime in the System.

                                    1         § 102712. Aid to visitors, grantees, permittees, or licensees
                                    2                        in emergencies
                                    3           (a) VISITORS.—The Secretary may aid visitors within a System unit in
                                    4         an emergency, when no other source is available for the procurement of food
                                    5         or supplies, by the sale, at cost, of food or supplies in quantities sufficient
                                    6         to enable the visitors to reach safely a point where food or supplies can be
                                    7         purchased. Receipts from the sales shall be deposited as a refund to the ap-
                                    8         propriation current at the date of the deposit and shall be available for the
                                    9         purchase of similar food or supplies.
                                  10            (b) GRANTEES, PERMITTEES,                AND     LICENSEES.—The Secretary may in
                                  11          an emergency, when no other source is available for the immediate procure-
                                  12          ment of supplies, materials, or special services, aid grantees, permittees, or
                                  13          licensees conducting operations for the benefit of the public in a System unit
                                  14          by the sale, at cost, including transportation and handling, of supplies, ma-
                                  15          terials, or special services as may be necessary to relieve the emergency and
                                  16          ensure uninterrupted service to the public. Receipts from the sales shall be
                                  17          deposited as a refund to the appropriation current at the date of the deposit
                                  18          and shall be available for expenditure for System unit purposes.

                                  20          § 102901. Conveyance of property and interests in property
                                  21                         in System units or related areas
                                  22            (a) FREEHOLD           AND   LEASEHOLD INTERESTS.—With respect to any prop-
                                  23          erty acquired by the Secretary within a System unit or related area, except
                                  24          property within national parks or within national monuments of scientific
                                  25          significance, the Secretary may convey a freehold or leasehold interest in the
                                  26          property, subject to such terms and conditions as will ensure the use of the
                                  27          property in a manner that is, in the judgment of the Secretary, consistent
                                  28          with the purpose for which the System unit or related area was authorized
                                  29          by Congress. The Secretary shall convey the interest to the highest bidder,
                                  30          in accordance with such regulations as the Secretary may prescribe. The
                                  31          conveyance shall be at not less than the fair market value of the interest,
                                  32          as determined by the Secretary, except that if the conveyance is proposed
                                  33          within 2 years after the property to be conveyed is acquired by the Sec-
                                  34          retary, the Secretary shall allow the last owner of record of the property
                                  35          30 days following the date on which the owner is notified by the Secretary
                                  36          in writing that the property is to be conveyed within which to notify the
                                  37          Secretary that the owner wishes to acquire the interest. On receiving the




                                  38          timely request, the Secretary shall convey the interest to the person, in ac-
                                  39          cordance with such regulations as the Secretary may prescribe, on payment
                                  40          or agreement to pay an amount equal to the highest bid price.

                                  35          § 103301. Military maneuvers
                                  36               To obtain practical benefits of great value to the country from the es-
                                  37          tablishment of national military parks, the parks and their approaches are

                                                HR 1068 IH

                                                                                          87
                                    1         declared to be national fields for military maneuvers for the Regular Army
                                    2         or Regular Air Force and the National Guard or militia of the States. Na-
                                    3         tional military parks shall be opened for those purposes only in the discre-
                                    4         tion of the Secretary, and under such regulations as the Secretary may pre-
                                    5         scribe.
                                    6         § 103302. Camps for military instruction
                                    7           (a) ASSEMBLING          OF   FORCES      AND     DETAILING        OF   INSTRUCTORS.—The
                                    8         Secretary of the Army or Secretary of the Air Force, within the limits of
                                    9         appropriations that may be available for that purpose, may assemble in
                                  10          camp at such season of the year and for such period as the Secretary of
                                  11          the Army or Secretary of the Air Force may designate, at the field of mili-
                                  12          tary maneuvers, such portions of the military forces of the United States
                                  13          as the Secretary of the Army or Secretary of the Air Force may think best,
                                  14          to receive military instruction there. The Secretary of the Army of Secretary
                                  15          of the Air Force may detail instructors from the Regular Army or Regular
                                  16          Air Force, respectively, for those forces during their exercises.
                                  17            (b) REGULATIONS.—The Secretary of the Army or Secretary of the Air
                                  18          Force may prescribe regulations governing the assembling of the National
                                  19          Guard or militia of the States on the maneuvering grounds.
                                  20          § 103303. Performance of duties of commissions
                                  21            The duties of commissions in charge of national military parks shall be
                                  22          performed under the direction of the Secretary.
                                  23          § 103304. Recovery of land withheld
                                  24            (a) CIVIL ACTION.—The United States may bring a civil action in the
                                  25          courts of the United States against a person to whom land lying within a
                                  26          national military park has been leased that refuses to give up possession of
                                  27          the land to the United States after the termination of the lease, and after
                                  28          possession has been demanded for the United States by the park super-
                                  29          intendent, or against a person retaining possession of land lying within the
                                  30          boundary of a national military park that the person has sold to the United
                                  31          States for park purposes and received payment therefor, after possession of
                                  32          the land has been demanded for the United States by the park super-
                                  33          intendent, to recover possession of the land withheld. The civil action shall
                                  34          be brought according to the statutes of the State in which the national mili-
                                  35          tary park is situated.
                                  36            (b) TRESPASS.—A person described in subsection (a) shall be guilty of
                                  37          trespass.
                                  38          § 103305. Travel expenses incident to study of battlefields

                                  40          traveling on duty in connection with the studies, surveys, and field investiga-
                                                HR 1068 IH

                                                                                          88
                                    1         tions of battlefields shall be paid from the appropriations made to meet ex-

                                    3         § 103306. Studies
                                    4           (a) STUDY       OF     BATTLEFIELDS       FOR     COMMEMORATIVE PURPOSES.—The

                                  12            (b) INCLUSION          OF   ESTIMATE    OF    COST   OF    PROJECTED SURVEYS          IN   AP-

                                  14          ally in the Department of the Interior appropriation estimates a list of the
                                  15          battlefields for which surveys or other field investigations are planned for
                                  16          the fiscal year in question, with the estimated cost of making each survey
                                  17          or other field investigation.
                                  18            (c) PURCHASE           OF   REAL ESTATE       FOR    NATIONAL MILITARY PARK PUR-

                                  10          § 104906. Protection of right of individuals to bear arms
                                  11            (a) FINDINGS.—Congress finds the following:
                                  12                  (1) The 2d amendment to the Constitution provides that ‘‘the right
                                  13               of the people to keep and bear Arms, shall not be infringed’’.
                                  14                  (2) Section 2.4(a)(1) of title 36, Code of Federal Regulations, pro-
                                  15               vides that ‘‘except as otherwise provided in this section and parts 7
                                  16               (special regulations) and 13 (Alaska regulations), the following are pro-
                                  17               hibited: (i) Possessing a weapon, trap or net (ii) Carrying a weapon,
                                  18               trap or net (iii) Using a weapon, trap or net’’.
                                  19                  (3) The regulations described in paragraph (2) prevent individuals
                                  20               complying with Federal and State laws from exercising the 2d amend-
                                  21               ment rights of the individuals while at System units.
                                  22                  (4) The existence of different laws relating to the transportation and
                                  23               possession of firearms at different System units entrapped law-abiding
                                  24               gun owners while at System units.
                                  25                  (5) Although the Bush administration issued new regulations relat-
                                  26               ing to the 2d amendment rights of law-abiding citizens in System units
                                  27               that went into effect on January 9, 2009—
                                  28                          (A) on March 19, 2009, the United States District Court for
                                  29                        the District of Columbia granted a preliminary injunction with re-
                                  30                        spect to the implementation and enforcement of the new regula-
                                  31                        tions; and
                                  32                          (B) the new regulations—
                                  33                                (i) are under review by the Obama administration; and
                                  34                                (ii) may be altered.
                                  35                  (6) Congress needs to weigh in on the new regulations to ensure that
                                  36               unelected bureaucrats and judges cannot again override the 2d amend-
                                  37               ment rights of law-abiding citizens on 83,600,000 acres of System land.
                                  38                  (7) Federal laws should make it clear that the 2d amendment rights
                                  39               of an individual at a System unit should not be infringed.





                                  40            (b) PROTECTION           OF   RIGHT   OF   INDIVIDUALS TO BEAR ARMS                    IN   SYSTEM
                                  41          UNITS.—The Secretary shall not promulgate or enforce any regulation that


                                               HR 1068 IH

                                                                                          91
                                    1         prohibits an individual from possessing a firearm, including an assembled
                                    2         or functional firearm, in any System unit if—
                                    3                 (1) the individual is not otherwise prohibited by law from possessing
                                    4              the firearm; and
                                    5                 (2) the possession of the firearm is in compliance with the law of
                                    6              the State in which the System unit is located.

                                          200101.      Findings and declaration of policy.
